newsitem.title: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: Four Australians killed in PNG aircraft crash.
newsitem.headline: Four Australians killed in PNG aircraft crash.

text.p: Four Australians, including a business executive and his son, were killed in an aircraft crash on Monday in the Papua New Guinea highlands near the Porgera gold mine, civil aviation authorities said on Tuesday.
The Piper Navajo aircraft crash landed and burst into flames at the Kairik airstrip in the Enga Province in central Papua New Guinea.

Reimund Frankiewicz, general manger of highlands-based retail company Bromley & Manton, his pilot son Dale, Nicholas Lee and another unidentified company executive were all killed when the aircraft crashed.
A fifth man, coffee grower George Leahy, survived with severe burns and was rushed to the Australian town of Cairns for treatment.

Civil aviation authorities said the aircraft veered towards the side of the airstrip, located in difficult terrain, flipped over and burst into flames. There was no initial indication of what caused the accident. Investigations were continuing.
The aircraft was owned by industrial and retail firm, Collins & Leahy.
